**Acme Co. Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.12: Workforce Reductions and the WARN Act**
*Revision Date: 2024-01-01*

Acme Co. is committed to treating all employees with fairness and respect. This policy outlines our procedures regarding workforce reductions, including mass layoffs and plant closures, and aims to comply with both federal and California law regarding advance notice.

**3.12.1 WARN Act Notification Requirements:**

Acme Co. is required to provide advance written notice to affected employees in the event of a qualifying mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation. A "mass layoff" under the federal Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act, 29 U.S.C. § 2101, et seq., is defined as a reduction in force (excluding terminations for cause, voluntary departures, or retirements) that results in an employment loss at a single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees, if those 50 employees represent at least 33% of the employees at the single site of employment, or 500 or more employees regardless of percentage. Under California's WARN Act, Cal. Labor Code sections 1400 et seq., a mass layoff is defined as the termination of 50 or more employees within a 30-day period.

**3.12.2 Notice Period:**

If Acme Co. employs 100 or more employees (nationwide), and a mass layoff or plant closure affecting 50 or more employees is planned, the company must provide at least 60 calendar days' advance written notice to affected employees, their representatives (if any), the State of California Employment Development Department (EDD), and the chief elected official of the local government. If the company employs 75 or more employees in California, and a mass layoff or plant closure affecting 50 or more employees occurs in California, the company must comply with California WARN regulations, providing 60 days' notice as described above. In situations where the employee is located in California, Acme Co. will always apply the California WARN act requirements. See also Section 3.13, Termination Procedures.

**Section 3.4: Family and Medical Leave**
**Revision Date: 2024-01-01**

3.4.1 **Eligibility for California Paid Family Leave (PFL)**: Pursuant to California Unemployment Insurance Code Sections 3300 et seq., employees of Titan Technologies, Inc., whose primary work location is within the State of California, shall be eligible for California Paid Family Leave (PFL) benefits, subject to the following conditions.

3.4.1.1 **SDI Contributions:** Eligibility for PFL is contingent upon the employee's participation in and contribution to the California State Disability Insurance (SDI) program, as mandated by California law. Only employees designated as SDI contributors, as determined by payroll records, shall be considered eligible. If the employee does not contribute to SDI (employee.sdi_contributor is false), then they are not eligible for PFL.

3.4.1.2 **Employment Status:** Notwithstanding any other provision within this Section, only active employees, those with an employment_status of 'active', are eligible to receive PFL benefits. Employees who are terminated, resigned, or laid off are ineligible for PFL. Employees must be currently working for Titan Technologies, Inc. at the time the leave commences.

3.4.1.3 **Concurrent FMLA:** Employees eligible for both California PFL and the federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) may take both leaves concurrently, to the extent permitted by law. Titan Technologies will designate leave as both FMLA and PFL where applicable. The maximum combined leave duration shall not exceed the total time authorized under both FMLA and PFL.

3.4.1.4 **Leave Duration Restrictions:** Consistent with California law, the maximum duration of PFL benefits shall not exceed eight (8) weeks within a twelve (12) month period. This limitation is applicable regardless of the qualifying reason for the leave (e.g., bonding with a new child, caring for a seriously ill family member). The reason for leave must be documented for compliance with CA PFL law.

**Sterling Consolidated HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.5: Paid Family Leave and Family Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**
**Revision Date:** 2024-01-15
**Effective Date:** 2024-02-01

This policy outlines Sterling Consolidated’s approach to Paid Family Leave (PFL) and the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA). We strive to comply with both California law and federal law, offering employees the best possible leave options within the legal framework.

**3.5.1 California Paid Family Leave (PFL)**

Employees who contribute to California State Disability Insurance (SDI) and work in California are generally eligible for California Paid Family Leave (PFL). This benefit provides partial wage replacement (approximately 60-70% of your normal wages) for up to 8 weeks to care for a seriously ill family member (child, parent, spouse, registered domestic partner, grandparent, grandchild, or sibling) or to bond with a new child (birth, adoption, or foster care placement). See Section 3.5.4 for concurrent FMLA and PFL leave provisions. An employee will not be terminated if their employment status is active and SDI contributions are being made. If the employee contributes to SDI, and is actively employed, they will not be terminated for using PFL as defined in this section.

**3.5.2 Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**

The Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) is a federal law providing eligible employees of Sterling Consolidated (where we have 50 or more employees within a 75-mile radius of your worksite) with up to 12 weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave per 12-month period for specified family and medical reasons. These reasons include the birth or adoption of a child; to care for a seriously ill family member (spouse, child, or parent); or due to the employee's own serious health condition that makes the employee unable to perform the essential functions of his or her job.

**3.5.3 Leave Coordination**

To the extent possible, Sterling Consolidated will coordinate California PFL and FMLA leave. Leave taken under California PFL will run concurrently with any FMLA leave entitlement when the leave qualifies for both. This means that the 8 weeks of PFL are part of, not in addition to, the 12 weeks allowed under FMLA.

**3.5.4 Termination during Leave**

Sterling Consolidated may consider termination during an active FMLA or PFL leave period if the employee's employment status changes from active to something else. For example, if an entire department is eliminated due to restructuring and the employee's role is eliminated, and that would lead to termination regardless of leave status, the employee’s employment may be terminated during the FMLA/PFL leave.

**Acme Corp. Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

Acme Corp. is committed to providing its employees with legally compliant meal and rest breaks. This policy outlines the company’s requirements regarding these breaks, considering both federal and California state laws.

**3.4.1 General Provisions**

Federal law does not mandate meal or rest breaks for adult employees. However, if Acme Corp. chooses to provide short breaks (5 to 20 minutes), these breaks must be paid. Meal breaks of 30 minutes or more are generally unpaid, provided the employee is completely relieved of all duties during the break. In California, however, the law requires very specific provisions regarding meal and rest breaks.

**3.4.2 California Specific Provisions**

Employees working in California are entitled to a 30-minute unpaid meal break if they work more than five (5) hours in a workday. A second 30-minute unpaid meal break is required if an employee works more than ten (10) hours in a workday. Additionally, California employees are entitled to a paid 10-minute rest break for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof. It is the employee’s responsibility to take these breaks. If a non-exempt employee works in California and their shift hours are greater than 5, AND they are *not* classified as exempt, then they are eligible for an unpaid 30 minute meal break. Please consult the “Exempt vs. Non-Exempt Classification” section of this handbook (Section 2.2) for further clarification on employee classifications.

**3.4.3 Break Waivers**

Under certain circumstances, California employees may waive their meal breaks. Please see Section 3.5 for more information on meal break waivers.

**3.4.4 Missed Breaks**

Any employee who is required to work through their meal break or rest break due to business necessity must immediately notify their supervisor. Acme Corp will provide compensation in accordance with California law for missed breaks.

**Apex Corporation HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.12: Workforce Reduction and WARN Act Compliance**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision Number: 2.0**

Apex Corporation is committed to complying with all applicable federal and state laws regarding workforce reductions. This policy outlines the procedures for mass layoffs, plant closures, and relocations, ensuring that we provide adequate notice to affected employees. This policy applies to all Apex Corporation employees in the United States.

**3.12.1 WARN Act Notification Requirements**

The Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act requires employers to provide advance notice of certain plant closings and mass layoffs. A "plant closing" is defined as the permanent or temporary shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, if the shutdown results in an employment loss for 50 or more employees during any 30-day period. A "mass layoff" is defined as a reduction in force that is not the result of a plant closing and that results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for either (1) 50 or more employees if they make up at least 33% of the employer's active workforce at the single site of employment; or (2) 500 or more employees, regardless of the percentage of the employer's active workforce at the single site of employment. "Employment loss" is generally defined as a termination, a layoff exceeding six months, or a reduction in hours of more than 50 percent during each month of any six-month period.

**3.12.2 California WARN Act Considerations**

In addition to the federal WARN Act, Apex Corporation acknowledges that California has its own version of the WARN Act, often referred to as the California WARN Act. The California WARN Act applies to employers with 75 or more employees (both full-time and part-time) and requires 60 days' advance written notice before a mass layoff, relocation, or plant closure affecting 50 or more employees within a 30-day period.

Therefore, if Apex Corporation has 75 or more employees within California, and a layoff will impact 50 or more employees, affected employees are entitled to 60 days' notice of the layoff. See Section 3.13 for severance information.

**Acme Corp. Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 3.14: Final Paycheck Disbursement**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01; Revision: 2.0**

3.14.1 General Policy: Acme Corp. is committed to ensuring compliance with all applicable federal and state wage and hour laws regarding the timely disbursement of final wages to separating employees. This policy governs the timing of final paycheck issuance for all employees, irrespective of employee.classification (exempt or non-exempt) or employee.pay_type (salaried or hourly), but is subject to the specific provisions outlined below. Any exceptions to this policy must be approved in writing by the Vice President of Human Resources and General Counsel.

3.14.2 Involuntary Termination: Pursuant to California Labor Code Section 201, notwithstanding any other provision of this Section, if an employee.location_state is 'CA' and employee.employment_status is 'terminated' through involuntary termination, the employee’s final paycheck, encompassing all wages earned and accrued vacation time, shall be made available to the employee immediately upon termination.

3.14.3 Voluntary Resignation: For employees who voluntarily resign from Acme Corp., the timing of the final paycheck will depend on the amount of notice provided. If an employee.location_state is 'CA' and employee.employment_status is 'resigned', and termination.notice_given is 'true' with termination.notice_hours equal to or greater than 72, the final paycheck shall be made available on the employee’s last day of employment. If termination.notice_hours is less than 72 hours, Acme Corp. shall make the final paycheck available to the employee within 72 hours of their last day of employment. Employees terminating employment in states other than California will receive their final paycheck no later than the next regularly scheduled payday.

3.14.4 Federal Compliance: To the extent that federal law (Fair Labor Standards Act) is more lenient than the state law governing final pay disbursement, Acme Corp. will adhere to the stricter of the two. For employees in states other than California whose employee.employment_status is not 'terminated', 'resigned' or 'laid_off', final pay will be disbursed on the next regularly scheduled payday, as required by federal law.

**Unified Global Enterprises, Inc. - Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 3.12: Workforce Reduction and WARN Act Compliance**
**Revision Date: 2024-09-01**
**Effective Date: 2025-01-01**

3.  12.1 General Policy. Unified Global Enterprises, Inc. (“the Company”) is committed to conducting workforce reductions, including mass layoffs, plant closures, and relocations, in a manner compliant with all applicable laws and regulations, specifically the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act of 1988 ("WARN Act," 29 U.S.C. § 2101 et seq.). This Section 3.12 outlines the Company’s policy regarding notifications related to workforce reductions.

4.  12.2 WARN Act Notification Requirements. Subject to the exclusions outlined in 3.12.3, in the event of a plant closing or mass layoff as defined by the federal WARN Act, the Company shall provide sixty (60) calendar days advance written notice to affected employees. For the purposes of this policy and compliance with the federal WARN Act, a "mass layoff" is defined as a reduction in force, not resulting from a plant closing, which results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees if these employees represent at least 33 percent of the employees (excluding employees employed on a part-time basis); or 500 or more employees (regardless of the percentage of the employees at the site).

5.  12.3 Exceptions and Conditions. Notwithstanding Section 3.12.2, the notice requirements may be reduced or eliminated under certain circumstances as explicitly provided in the federal WARN Act. These circumstances include, but are not limited to, unforeseeable business circumstances (as defined in 29 U.S.C. § 2102(b)(2)(A)), faltering company (as defined in 29 U.S.C. § 2102(b)(1)), and natural disaster (as defined in 29 U.S.C. § 2102(b)(2)(B)). The Company will determine the applicability of these exceptions on a case-by-case basis and will document its reasoning. Furthermore, if the affected employee count is not_in the range of 50 to 499 employees, the Company will evaluate the percentage impact on the employee base, and provide 60 days notification if the number of employees affected represents at least 33 percent of the employees at the site. The Company aims to fulfill the spirit of the WARN Act even when strict legal triggers are not met.

**Effective Date: 2024-07-01, Revision 1.2**

This policy outlines Sterling Innovations’ approach to Family and Medical Leave, balancing both federal and California state regulations. We are committed to supporting our employees' needs to care for their families and manage personal health matters.

**5.2.1 Eligibility Overview**

Sterling Innovations complies with both the federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) and California Paid Family Leave (PFL). It's important to understand that FMLA provides *unpaid*, job-protected leave for up to 12 weeks in a 12-month period for qualifying reasons, such as the birth or adoption of a child, caring for a seriously ill family member (spouse, child, or parent), or the employee's own serious health condition. FMLA applies to employees who have worked for Sterling Innovations for at least 12 months, have worked at least 1,250 hours in the 12 months before the leave, and if Sterling Innovations has 50 or more employees within a 75-mile radius of your worksite.

California PFL, on the other hand, provides *partial wage replacement* (currently 60-70% of your usual wages) for up to 8 weeks for bonding with a new child or caring for a seriously ill family member (child, parent, spouse, grandparent, grandchild, sibling, or registered domestic partner). To be eligible for CA PFL, you must contribute to California State Disability Insurance (SDI). Employees who are not SDI contributors are not eligible for PFL benefits, even if they are eligible for FMLA. If you work in California, you likely contribute to SDI, but please confirm this on your paystub. You may take PFL to care for family members NOT residing in California, so long as you otherwise meet the eligibility requirements. Note that, depending on the timing and overlap between FMLA and PFL, FMLA runs concurrently with PFL where applicable. The laws are often paired together when leave is requested.

**4.0 Workforce Reduction Policy**
**4.1 WARN Act Compliance**

4.1.1. It is the policy of Acme Innovations to comply with all applicable federal and state laws regarding workforce reductions, including the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act, 29 U.S.C. § 2101 et seq., and the California WARN Act, Cal. Labor Code § 1400 et seq.

4.1.2. *Notification Requirement*. Notwithstanding any other provision of this policy, if Acme Innovations contemplates a plant closing or mass layoff, as defined below, at a facility located in California, affected employees shall be entitled to a sixty (60) day advance written notice of such plant closing or mass layoff, provided that Acme Innovations employs 75 or more employees at that physical worksite location, or if the mass layoff affects 50 or more employees at a single site of employment within California. However, the notification requirement pursuant to this policy will be triggered *only if* the total number of employees employed by Acme Innovations company-wide is less than 100; otherwise, compliance with the federal WARN act is sufficient. **Section 3.2: Overtime Compensation (California Employees)**
**Revision: 1.0**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**

This section outlines Apex Solutions, Inc.'s policy regarding overtime compensation for non-exempt employees working in the state of California. This policy is intended to comply with all applicable California state laws. Please note that this policy applies only to employees whose employee.location_state is 'CA'; overtime for employees working in other states is governed by the laws of those states and applicable federal law, as described in Section 3.3. All other Apex Solutions, Inc. policies apply in addition to, and not in lieu of, this policy.

**Overtime Pay:**

Apex Solutions, Inc. provides overtime compensation to its non-exempt California employees as follows:

*   **Daily Overtime:** If an employee's employee.classification is 'non_exempt' and their employee.location_state is 'CA', they will be paid one and one-half (1.5) times their regular rate of pay for all hours worked in excess of eight (8) hours in any workday (employee.hours_worked_daily) and up to and including twelve (12) hours in any workday.

*   **Double Time:** If an employee's employee.classification is 'non_exempt' and their employee.location_state is 'CA', they will be paid two (2) times their regular rate of pay for all hours worked in excess of twelve (12) hours in any workday (employee.hours_worked_daily).

*   **Weekly Overtime:** If an employee's employee.classification is 'non_exempt' and their employee.location_state is 'CA', and they have not already received overtime pay under the Daily Overtime provisions, they will be paid one and one-half (1.5) times their regular rate of pay for all hours worked in excess of forty (40) hours in any workweek (employee.hours_worked_weekly). Hours already compensated at the daily overtime rate are not included in the calculation of weekly overtime to avoid double-counting. This also applies for work that is not on the 7th consecutive day of the workweek.

*   **Seventh Consecutive Day Overtime:** If an employee's employee.classification is 'non_exempt', their employee.location_state is 'CA', and their employee.consecutive_workdays is not_in ["1", "2", "3", "4", "5", "6"], they will be paid one and one-half (1.5) times their regular rate of pay for the first eight (8) hours worked on the seventh consecutive day of work in a workweek. All hours worked in excess of eight (8) on the seventh consecutive day of work in a workweek will be paid at two (2) times the employee's regular rate of pay.

Employees are required to accurately record all hours worked each day. Falsification of time records may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment. Any questions regarding overtime eligibility or compensation should be directed to the Human Resources Department.

**Section 3.12: Workforce Reduction and WARN Act Compliance**
**Revision Number:** 2.0
**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01

GlobalCorp is committed to complying with all applicable labor laws, including the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act, both at the federal level and within individual states. This policy outlines the procedures to be followed in the event of a plant closing or mass layoff.

A "plant closing" refers to the permanent or temporary shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, if the shutdown results in an employment loss during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees, excluding any part-time employees. A "mass layoff" means a reduction in force which is not the result of a plant closing, and which results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees if these 50 or more employees make up at least 33% of the employees at the single site of employment, or 500 or more employees regardless of the 33% threshold. For avoidance of doubt, a "single site of employment" can refer to either a single physical location or a group of contiguous locations.

GlobalCorp will provide written notice of any plant closing or mass layoff to affected employees and relevant government entities as required by law. While federal WARN requires employers with 100 or more employees to provide 60 days' notice, California's WARN Act (Cal-WARN) has different requirements. Therefore, if GlobalCorp plans a mass layoff that will affect 50 or more employees within California, and GlobalCorp employs 75 or more total employees, those California-based employees are entitled to at least 60 calendar days’ notice.

**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

ACME Corp. is committed to providing employees with legally compliant meal and rest breaks. This policy applies to all ACME Corp. employees in the United States, with specific provisions for employees in California due to stricter state regulations. For definitions of terms used in this policy, please refer to Section 1.2, “Definitions.”

**3.4.1 Federal Guidelines:**

Federal law does not mandate meal or rest breaks for adult employees. However, ACME Corp. adheres to the following federal guidelines regarding breaks:
*   Breaks lasting 5 to 20 minutes are considered working time and must be paid.
*   Meal periods of 30 minutes or more are unpaid, provided the employee is completely relieved of all duties and responsibilities during the entire meal period.

**3.4.2 California-Specific Regulations:**

Employees working in California are subject to the following additional requirements under California law:
*   **Meal Breaks:** Employees working more than five (5) hours in a workday are entitled to a 30-minute unpaid meal break. Employees working more than ten (10) hours in a workday are entitled to a second 30-minute unpaid meal break. These meal breaks must begin before the end of the fifth hour and tenth hour of work, respectively. Employees can waive their meal break if working no more than six (6) hours in a day, and if mutually agreed upon with the employer.
*   **Rest Breaks:** Employees are entitled to a paid 10-minute rest break for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof. Rest breaks should be taken in the middle of each four-hour work period, as practicable.
*   **Premium Pay for Missed Breaks:** If an employee is not provided with a compliant meal or rest break, the employee is entitled to one (1) hour of premium pay for each workday that a meal or rest break is missed. Please see Section 3.4.3 for instructions on reporting missed breaks.

**3.4.3 Reporting Missed Breaks:**

Any employee who believes they have been denied a compliant meal or rest break should immediately report the missed break to their supervisor or Human Resources. Employees must notify HR immediately if they are not located in one of the following states: California, New York, Texas, Florida, Washington, Pennsylvania, Illinois, Ohio, Georgia, North Carolina, Michigan, New Jersey, Virginia, Arizona, Massachusetts, Tennessee, Indiana, Maryland, Missouri, Wisconsin, Colorado, Minnesota, South Carolina, Alabama, Louisiana, Kentucky, Oregon, Oklahoma, Connecticut, Utah, Iowa, Nevada, Arkansas, Mississippi, Kansas, New Mexico, Nebraska, Idaho, West Virginia, Hawaii, New Hampshire, Maine, Montana, Rhode Island, Delaware, South Dakota, North Dakota, Alaska, Vermont, Wyoming to ensure the company can track and remediate any missed breaks.

**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01; Revision 2.0**

This policy outlines Sterling Solutions, Inc.'s (the "Company") approach to meal and rest breaks for all employees. It is our intention to fully comply with all applicable federal and state laws, including those specific to California. This policy applies to all active employees of Sterling Solutions, Inc. and its subsidiaries. Please refer to Section 1.2 (Definitions) for clarification of terms used herein.

**3.4.1 General Guidelines**

Sterling Solutions, Inc. provides meal and rest breaks to employees as required by law. The following guidelines apply:

*   **Federal Law:** Under federal law, Sterling Solutions, Inc. is not required to provide meal or rest breaks to employees. However, when breaks of short duration (usually lasting from 5 to 20 minutes) are offered, Sterling Solutions, Inc. will compensate its employees for such time. Any meal periods lasting 30 minutes or more will be unpaid, provided that the employee is completely relieved of their duties during the meal period.

*   **California Law:** For employees working in California, California law mandates specific meal and rest break requirements. Employees are entitled to a 30-minute unpaid meal break if they work more than five (5) hours in a workday. A second 30-minute unpaid meal break is required if an employee works more than ten (10) hours in a workday. **Section 3.12: Workforce Reductions and the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act**

**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01
**Revision:** 1.0

Acme Corp is committed to treating its employees with respect and consideration during periods of workforce reduction. The Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act is a federal law designed to protect workers, their families, and communities by requiring employers to provide notification 60 calendar days in advance of plant closings and mass layoffs. This policy outlines Acme Corp's obligations under the federal WARN Act. Note this policy adheres only to the federal requirements, and does not provide additional or differing requirements of any state.

**3.12.1 WARN Act Notification Requirements**

Acme Corp will provide advance written notice of a plant closing or mass layoff as required by the federal WARN Act. A *plant closing* is defined as the permanent or temporary shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, if the shutdown results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees, excluding any part-time employees. A *mass layoff* is defined as a reduction in force which is not the result of a plant closing, but results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees and represents at least 33% of the employees at the single site of employment, excluding any part-time employees, or 500 or more employees are affected regardless of percentage. For the purposes of this policy, *employment loss* means (1) an employment termination, other than a discharge for cause, voluntary departure, or retirement; (2) a layoff exceeding 6 months; or (3) a reduction in hours of work of more than 50 percent during each month of any 6-month period.

Therefore, Acme Corp will notify affected employees 60 calendar days in advance of a mass layoff if the number of affected employees in that mass layoff is greater than or equal to 50 and also represents at least 33% of the employees at the single site of employment, OR the number of affected employees is greater than or equal to 500, given the employer has 100 or more employees.

**3.12.2 Notice Content**

The WARN notice will include, but is not limited to, the following information: the name and address of the employment site where the plant closing or mass layoff will occur; the nature of the planned action; the expected date of the first separation; a statement as to whether the planned action is expected to be permanent or temporary; the job titles of positions to be affected and the number of affected employees in each job classification; and contact information for company officials to contact for further information.

Acme Corp. provides meal breaks to ensure the health and well-being of its employees. In accordance with California law, if an employee is not provided with a compliant meal or rest break, Acme Corp. will pay the employee one (1) hour of pay at the employee’s regular rate of compensation for each workday that a meal or rest break is not provided.

**Section 3.4: Family and Medical Leave Policy (FMLA)**
**Revision 1.0**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**

Acme Corp. is committed to supporting its employees' needs related to family and medical care. This policy outlines the provisions for Family and Medical Leave in accordance with the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) of 1993. Eligibility for FMLA leave is determined by federal regulations, specifically those outlined in 29 U.S.C. § 2611, et seq., and 29 CFR Part 825, which are incorporated herein by reference.

**3.4.1 FMLA Leave Provisions**

Subject to the eligibility requirements outlined below and provided that the employee has already used any available paid leave under Section 3.3, an eligible employee of Acme Corp. will be granted up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave during any 12-month period for the following reasons:

*   The birth of a child and to bond with the newborn child within one year of birth;
*   The placement with the employee of a child for adoption or foster care and to bond with the newly placed child within one year of placement;
*   To care for the employee's spouse, child, or parent who has a serious health condition;
*   A serious health condition that makes the employee unable to perform the essential functions of his or her job;
*   Any qualifying exigency arising out of the fact that the employee's spouse, son, daughter, or parent is a covered military member on active duty (or has been notified of an impending call or order to active duty) in the Armed Forces.

Eligibility for FMLA leave is contingent upon an employee having been employed by Acme Corp. for at least 12 months and having worked at least 1,250 hours during the 12-month period immediately preceding the commencement of the leave. Furthermore, FMLA leave is only available if Acme Corp. employs 50 or more employees within a 75-mile radius of the employee's worksite. Requests for leave exceeding 12 weeks may be considered under Section 3.5: Extended Leave, but such leave will be at the discretion of the company and subject to business needs. Failure to return to work immediately following the twelve weeks granted may impact re-employment as described under Termination, Section 5.1.
